column4: A Greek hoplite, armed with spear and shield]]

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: '''Hoplology''' is a science that studies human combative behavior and performance.
The word ''hoplology'' is derived from the [[Greek language
date=March 2014}}: Greek]] terms ''hoplos'' (a mythical plate-armored animal) and ὅπλον ''hóplon'', a wooden shield carried by some warriors in ancient Greece.  The word ''[[hoplite]]'', derived from ''hoplon'', is the term for the classical Greek [[warrior]] who carried such a shield. The field originates in the 19th century with [[Richard Francis Burton
column3: Sir Richard Burton]]; although the origin of the word is often attributed to Burton, there are earlier references to it.<ref name=\"hacc1\" />  Despite the work of Burton and a few others, it was not until the 1960s that hoplology took shape as an academic field of study under the leadership of [[Donn F. Draeger]].<ref name=\"hacc1\">{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Hoplology was at some time defined as the science of \"arms and weapons of offense and defence, human and bestial\" (Burton, 1884),<ref>Richard Francis Burton - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=MGmbAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+swords&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAGoVChMI6e-j2pL8xgIVAu8UCh2lYglG#v=onepage&q=History%20of%20swords&f=false The Book of the Sword: A History of Daggers, Sabers, and Scimitars from Ancient Times to the Modern Day - 7th page of ''Chapter 1 - Preamble: on the Origin of Weapons''] published by [[Skyhorse Publishing]], Inc. 20 November 2013, 336 pages, {{ISBN
date=March 2014}}: 1628738472}} [Retrieved 2015-07-27]</ref> and subsequently as \"the study of the basis, patterns, relationships, and significances of combative behavior at all levels of social complexity\" (Draeger, 1982).<ref name=\"hoplology.com\">International Hoplology Society - [http://www.hoplology.com/about.htm home-page] published by the International Hoplology Society, Inc. 1998-2007</ref>

black belt]] level, [[tenth dan]]-ranked in [[karate]], defines hoplology as \"the study of the evolution and development of human combatitive behaviour and performance ... the study of how people fight, why they fight, and how different cultures manifest those behaviours.\"<ref>Sid Campbell - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZHdRcezT3bwC&pg=PA184&dq=hoplology&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAzgeahUKEwitmv7B2YHHAhVC1hQKHUIMDg8#v=onepage&q=hoplology&f=false Warrior Arts and Weapons of Ancient Hawai'i] Blue Snake Books 2006, 266 pages, {{ISBN

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: More recently, hoplology is defined as the investigation and analysis of all forms of armed combat. It is most productively seen as an embodied event where the physiological and neurological structures of those individuals taking part in a combative encounter shape and, in turn, are shaped by cultural norms of what is right, effective, and efficient and so changes overtime and across space. As in all human encounters, every combat event is accompanied by a form of material technology and has been learned through a process of apprenticeship.

Several pioneering Anthropologists were also contributing to the field of Hoplology while Burton was active.  A retired military officer who fought in the Crimean War, A.H.L. Pitt-Rivers developed a now outdated view of human evolution.  Cultures, he concluded, evolved through time from technologically simpler societies to technologically complex societies. In other words, progress is an integral aspect of human history. Primitive Warfare 2. Oxford: The Journal of the Royal United Service Institution Vol. XII 1868 NO. LI. Working in the Trobriand Islands (just off Australia) around the time of WWI, the renowned Anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski also delved into the field of Hoplology. \"War and Weapons Among the Natives of the Trobriand Islands\". Man. Vol. 20 pg.10-12 (1920).

Hoplology has always had a theoretical and practical orientation. Seeking to introduce more effective forms of close quarter combat to British soldiers Burton wrote two instructional manuals “ A Complete System of Bayonet Fighting.” London: William Clowes and Sons. 1853. And “A New System of Sword exercise for Infantry.” London: William Clowes and Sons.1876. while the memoir by the ex-Hussar F.J Norman’s  “The Fighting Man of Japan: the training and exercise of the samurai.” London: Archibald Constable & CO.

During the post WWII era the International Hoplology Society (\"IHS\") was established by Major Donn F. Draeger (USMC Ret.) to study the evolution and development of human combative behavior. Draeger had prior research and personal experience of classical fighting systems. Draeger's student and colleague, Hunter B. Armstrong, went on to carry on Draeger's project as director of IHS. He continues closely with military and law enforcement, and has been central to the most recent recreation of the [[Marine Corps Martial Arts Program]] (MCMAP). Also, during this time working with Basil Richardson of the Victoria and Albert Museum, Roald Knutsen's wrote \"Japanese Spear: Polearms and Their Use in Old Japan\" (1963). Here he not only described the morphology of these weapons but explored how they were used by different schools or “ryu.”<ref>Masters Magazine Spring 2019 pg 35</ref>.

During the 1970's, The Republic of China began a number of  academically based (and often government funded) investigations into several folk combat traditions.  One drawback to many of these works is that they have yet to be translated in English, limiting the exposure of their findings.  In other cases, they were inspired by ethno-nationalist or ideological considerations and no real effort has been made to engage with the growing international literature on Martial Arts Studies.

More recently Anthropologists and other scholars have begun increasingly to examine how local people actually fight with weapons. Ethnographies such as Michael Ryan's [https://www.amazon.com/Venezuelan-Stick-Fighting-Civilizing-Process/dp/1498533205 Venezuelan Stick Fighting: The Civilizing Process in Martial Arts (2016)]. Philip Forde’s recently completed doctoral dissertation “Blocking both Hand and Foot: An Examination of Bajan Sticklicking” (2018) is another informative work. Avron Boretz’s [https://www.amazon.com/Gods-Ghosts-Gangsters-Violence-Masculinity/dp/0824834917 Gods, Ghosts, and Gangsters: Ritual Violence, Martial Arts and Masculinity on the Margins of Chinese Society] (2011) describes Kung Fu training with working-class men and petty criminals in rural Taiwan. Pentjak Silat on the island of Java was explored by Lee Wilson in [https://www.amazon.com/Indonesia-Verhandelingen-Koninklijk-Instituut-Volmenkunde/dp/9004287736 Martial Arts and the Body Politic in Indonesia] (2015).

In 2017 we saw an emergence of a New Hoplology, pioneered by The Immersion Projects. Immersion Projects continue to lead multiple expeditions, sponsor symposiums and launched a new journal<ref>The Immersion Review, www.TheImmersionMedia.com/review</ref> focused on the study of combat.

Hoplology encompasses the segment of human culture concerned with weapons, armor, combative accoutrements and fighting systems, in regard to their technical characteristics and the ways in which they interact with the economic, political, social and religious institutions of human societies, and  has three main research areas: technological, functional, and behavioral.
* Technological hoplology studies the development of weapons, armor, and other combative tools in relation to the contexts in which they are created.
*Functional hoplology delves into the structure, development, and organization of combative systems and their relationship to the application of fighting and weapons.

* Behavioral hoplology encompasses the psychological and physiological factors that affect human’s combative behavior and development of combative capabilities such as weapons or fighting systems. The broad subject range of behavioral hoplology means it also includes the effects that culture has had on man’s evolution as a group-social animal.
There are three widely accepted axioms in hoplological studies.<ref name=\"hoplology.com\"/>
* human combative behavior is rooted in man’s [[Human evolution
* humans exhibit two types of aggression: affective aggression and predatory aggression. Both forms evolved from different survival needs as both a group-social animal and as a hunting animal.
* the evolution of human combative behavior is directly linked to the use of weapons. That is to say that the use of weapons is linked with and reflects combative performance and behavior.
A variation on the pragmatics of hoplological understanding is found in theatrical representations of combat.<ref name=\"Meron Langsner\">{{cite book
column11: chapter=Chapter 10. Theatre Hoplology: simulations and representations of violence on the stage
column12: page=112}}</ref>  While hoplology is still in its infancy, it has become an accepted area of study by scholars in several related disciplines such as [[combative psychology]], [[killology]], [[anthropology]], and [[military history]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The entrenched nature of violence in human behavior is generally well understood. The skill and potential of deadly aggression is something within human genetics which predisposes humans to violent behavior. However, the genetics that predispose humans to violence is highly influenced by environmental factors. Humans will only tap into their violent potential once the need has arisen. Human genetics have developed an on-off switch in the brain. On the on side \"…the fighting activity itself is stimulated by individual and communal thrill, enjoyment in the competitive exercise of spiritual and physical faculties, and even cruelty, blood lust, and killing ecstasy.\" (Gat 2006) On the off-side violence is deterred away by emotions through fear, revulsion at violence and bloodshed, physical fatigue, compassion, and spirituality. So if the environmental factors that cause a man to be violent are present, then he will be violent. If the environmental factors that cause a man to be violent are not present, he will abstain and deter violence.<ref>Gat, Azar. War in Human Civilization. New York: Oxford UP, USA, 2006. Print</ref>

In 2018 a group of academics and veteran martial artists came together to explore the roots of bodily movements with weapons to uncover any underlying principles that shape all combat. Under the flag of a \"[https://www.TheImmersionMedia.com New Hoplology]\" they conceptualized this study as an interdisciplinary project where in consideration of the diversity of its members, different research questions could be explored during the same project. One feeling shared among the group was to identify the most highly skilled exponents of combative systems. Those that were in the past and still today, first and foremost are seen and treated as combative arts that they have not evolved into modern recreations, sporting activities, folkloric representations of a past time. Next, they sought to conduct in-depth interviews and archive their system so s to provide a repository of data for future scholars and martial artists. Due to the nature of the project, these would be short term yet intensive research projects (typically ten 14-16 hour days of deep immersion in the cosmology, belief systems, history and combat methods). They are not meant to replace longer ethnographic research but to enhance and support other forms of research.
The multidisciplinary team, under the flag of the New Hoplology has organized the following expeditions to date
# Trinidadian Kalinda and Toboggan Jab Jab in the Caribbean<ref>https://chinesemartialstudies.com/2019/03/14/the-new-hoplology-stick-machete-and-whip-fighting-in-the-caribbean/</ref>

date=March 2014}}: Jogo De Pau]] expedition in Fafe, Portugal<ref>https://em3video.com/2020-spring-issue-masters-magazine-frames-video-free-download/</ref>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The first of these interdisciplinary expeditions was a roaring success in terms of collecting over 80 hours of film in a seldom seen art of  [[Bajan stick-licking
date=March 2014}}: Bajan Sticklicking]]. This was complemented by an equally in depth exploration of the arts of [[Calinda
column3: Trinidadian Kalinda]] and the seldom taught Afro-Indian whip art of [https://www.traditionalmas.com/project/jab-jab-2/ Jab-Jab]<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Traditional Mas Characters - Devils and Jab Jab
column7: access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref>. The entire expedition ended with a day of comparing & contrasting the arts of Bajan Sticklicking, Trinidadian Kalinda, Toboggan Jab-Jab, Venezuelan Garotte and Colombian Grima This was the first per all the keepers of these arts. The entire expedition was also covered in detail with a special free edition of the [https://em3video.com/masters-magazine-special-edition-free-spring-2019/ Masters Magazine] aptly called \"The Phoenix Rises.<ref>{{Cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: *Draeger, Donn F. (1979). ''An Introduction to Hoplology: Part I of II,'' Hoplos 1:1

column3: Sir Richard Burton]]; although the origin of the word is often attributed to Burton, there are earlier references to it.<ref name=\"hacc1\" />  Despite the work of Burton and a few others, it was not until the 1960s that hoplology took shape as an academic field of study under the leadership of [[Donn F. Draeger]].<ref name=\"hacc1\">{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Hoplology was at some time defined as the science of \"arms and weapons of offense and defence, human and bestial\" (Burton, 1884),<ref>Richard Francis Burton - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=MGmbAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+swords&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAGoVChMI6e-j2pL8xgIVAu8UCh2lYglG#v=onepage&q=History%20of%20swords&f=false The Book of the Sword: A History of Daggers, Sabers, and Scimitars from Ancient Times to the Modern Day - 7th page of ''Chapter 1 - Preamble: on the Origin of Weapons''] published by [[Skyhorse Publishing]], Inc. 20 November 2013, 336 pages, {{ISBN
date=March 2014}}: 1628738472}} [Retrieved 2015-07-27]</ref> and subsequently as \"the study of the basis, patterns, relationships, and significances of combative behavior at all levels of social complexity\" (Draeger, 1982).<ref name=\"hoplology.com\">International Hoplology Society - [http://www.hoplology.com/about.htm home-page] published by the International Hoplology Society, Inc. 1998-2007</ref>

black belt]] level, [[tenth dan]]-ranked in [[karate]], defines hoplology as \"the study of the evolution and development of human combatitive behaviour and performance ... the study of how people fight, why they fight, and how different cultures manifest those behaviours.\"<ref>Sid Campbell - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZHdRcezT3bwC&pg=PA184&dq=hoplology&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAzgeahUKEwitmv7B2YHHAhVC1hQKHUIMDg8#v=onepage&q=hoplology&f=false Warrior Arts and Weapons of Ancient Hawai'i] Blue Snake Books 2006, 266 pages, {{ISBN

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: More recently, hoplology is defined as the investigation and analysis of all forms of armed combat. It is most productively seen as an embodied event where the physiological and neurological structures of those individuals taking part in a combative encounter shape and, in turn, are shaped by cultural norms of what is right, effective, and efficient and so changes overtime and across space. As in all human encounters, every combat event is accompanied by a form of material technology and has been learned through a process of apprenticeship.

Several pioneering Anthropologists were also contributing to the field of Hoplology while Burton was active.  A retired military officer who fought in the Crimean War, A.H.L. Pitt-Rivers developed a now outdated view of human evolution.  Cultures, he concluded, evolved through time from technologically simpler societies to technologically complex societies. In other words, progress is an integral aspect of human history. Primitive Warfare 2. Oxford: The Journal of the Royal United Service Institution Vol. XII 1868 NO. LI. Working in the Trobriand Islands (just off Australia) around the time of WWI, the renowned Anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski also delved into the field of Hoplology. \"War and Weapons Among the Natives of the Trobriand Islands\". Man. Vol. 20 pg.10-12 (1920).

Hoplology has always had a theoretical and practical orientation. Seeking to introduce more effective forms of close quarter combat to British soldiers Burton wrote two instructional manuals “ A Complete System of Bayonet Fighting.” London: William Clowes and Sons. 1853. And “A New System of Sword exercise for Infantry.” London: William Clowes and Sons.1876. while the memoir by the ex-Hussar F.J Norman’s  “The Fighting Man of Japan: the training and exercise of the samurai.” London: Archibald Constable & CO.

During the post WWII era the International Hoplology Society (\"IHS\") was established by Major Donn F. Draeger (USMC Ret.) to study the evolution and development of human combative behavior. Draeger had prior research and personal experience of classical fighting systems. Draeger's student and colleague, Hunter B. Armstrong, went on to carry on Draeger's project as director of IHS. He continues closely with military and law enforcement, and has been central to the most recent recreation of the [[Marine Corps Martial Arts Program]] (MCMAP). Also, during this time working with Basil Richardson of the Victoria and Albert Museum, Roald Knutsen's wrote \"Japanese Spear: Polearms and Their Use in Old Japan\" (1963). Here he not only described the morphology of these weapons but explored how they were used by different schools or “ryu.”<ref>Masters Magazine Spring 2019 pg 35</ref>.

During the 1970's, The Republic of China began a number of  academically based (and often government funded) investigations into several folk combat traditions.  One drawback to many of these works is that they have yet to be translated in English, limiting the exposure of their findings.  In other cases, they were inspired by ethno-nationalist or ideological considerations and no real effort has been made to engage with the growing international literature on Martial Arts Studies.

More recently Anthropologists and other scholars have begun increasingly to examine how local people actually fight with weapons. Ethnographies such as Michael Ryan's [https://www.amazon.com/Venezuelan-Stick-Fighting-Civilizing-Process/dp/1498533205 Venezuelan Stick Fighting: The Civilizing Process in Martial Arts (2016)]. Philip Forde’s recently completed doctoral dissertation “Blocking both Hand and Foot: An Examination of Bajan Sticklicking” (2018) is another informative work. Avron Boretz’s [https://www.amazon.com/Gods-Ghosts-Gangsters-Violence-Masculinity/dp/0824834917 Gods, Ghosts, and Gangsters: Ritual Violence, Martial Arts and Masculinity on the Margins of Chinese Society] (2011) describes Kung Fu training with working-class men and petty criminals in rural Taiwan. Pentjak Silat on the island of Java was explored by Lee Wilson in [https://www.amazon.com/Indonesia-Verhandelingen-Koninklijk-Instituut-Volmenkunde/dp/9004287736 Martial Arts and the Body Politic in Indonesia] (2015).

In 2017 we saw an emergence of a New Hoplology, pioneered by The Immersion Projects. Immersion Projects continue to lead multiple expeditions, sponsor symposiums and launched a new journal<ref>The Immersion Review, www.TheImmersionMedia.com/review</ref> focused on the study of combat.

Hoplology encompasses the segment of human culture concerned with weapons, armor, combative accoutrements and fighting systems, in regard to their technical characteristics and the ways in which they interact with the economic, political, social and religious institutions of human societies, and  has three main research areas: technological, functional, and behavioral.
* Technological hoplology studies the development of weapons, armor, and other combative tools in relation to the contexts in which they are created.
*Functional hoplology delves into the structure, development, and organization of combative systems and their relationship to the application of fighting and weapons.

* Behavioral hoplology encompasses the psychological and physiological factors that affect human’s combative behavior and development of combative capabilities such as weapons or fighting systems. The broad subject range of behavioral hoplology means it also includes the effects that culture has had on man’s evolution as a group-social animal.
There are three widely accepted axioms in hoplological studies.<ref name=\"hoplology.com\"/>
* human combative behavior is rooted in man’s [[Human evolution
* humans exhibit two types of aggression: affective aggression and predatory aggression. Both forms evolved from different survival needs as both a group-social animal and as a hunting animal.
* the evolution of human combative behavior is directly linked to the use of weapons. That is to say that the use of weapons is linked with and reflects combative performance and behavior.
A variation on the pragmatics of hoplological understanding is found in theatrical representations of combat.<ref name=\"Meron Langsner\">{{cite book
column11: chapter=Chapter 10. Theatre Hoplology: simulations and representations of violence on the stage
column12: page=112}}</ref>  While hoplology is still in its infancy, it has become an accepted area of study by scholars in several related disciplines such as [[combative psychology]], [[killology]], [[anthropology]], and [[military history]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The entrenched nature of violence in human behavior is generally well understood. The skill and potential of deadly aggression is something within human genetics which predisposes humans to violent behavior. However, the genetics that predispose humans to violence is highly influenced by environmental factors. Humans will only tap into their violent potential once the need has arisen. Human genetics have developed an on-off switch in the brain. On the on side \"…the fighting activity itself is stimulated by individual and communal thrill, enjoyment in the competitive exercise of spiritual and physical faculties, and even cruelty, blood lust, and killing ecstasy.\" (Gat 2006) On the off-side violence is deterred away by emotions through fear, revulsion at violence and bloodshed, physical fatigue, compassion, and spirituality. So if the environmental factors that cause a man to be violent are present, then he will be violent. If the environmental factors that cause a man to be violent are not present, he will abstain and deter violence.<ref>Gat, Azar. War in Human Civilization. New York: Oxford UP, USA, 2006. Print</ref>

In 2018 a group of academics and veteran martial artists came together to explore the roots of bodily movements with weapons to uncover any underlying principles that shape all combat. Under the flag of a \"[https://www.TheImmersionMedia.com New Hoplology]\" they conceptualized this study as an interdisciplinary project where in consideration of the diversity of its members, different research questions could be explored during the same project. One feeling shared among the group was to identify the most highly skilled exponents of combative systems. Those that were in the past and still today, first and foremost are seen and treated as combative arts that they have not evolved into modern recreations, sporting activities, folkloric representations of a past time. Next, they sought to conduct in-depth interviews and archive their system so s to provide a repository of data for future scholars and martial artists. Due to the nature of the project, these would be short term yet intensive research projects (typically ten 14-16 hour days of deep immersion in the cosmology, belief systems, history and combat methods). They are not meant to replace longer ethnographic research but to enhance and support other forms of research.
The multidisciplinary team, under the flag of the New Hoplology has organized the following expeditions to date
# Trinidadian Kalinda and Toboggan Jab Jab in the Caribbean

date=March 2014}}: Jogo De Pau]] expedition in Fafe, Portugal

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The first of these interdisciplinary expeditions was a roaring success in terms of collecting over 80 hours of film in a seldom seen art of  [[Bajan stick-licking

column3: Trinidadian Kalinda]] and the seldom taught Afro-Indian whip art of [https://www.traditionalmas.com/project/jab-jab-2/ Jab-Jab]<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Traditional Mas Characters - Devils and Jab Jab
column7: access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref>. The entire expedition ended with a day of comparing & contrasting the arts of Bajan Sticklicking, Trinidadian Kalinda, Toboggan Jab-Jab, Venezuelan Garotte and Colombian Grima This was the first per all the keepers of these arts. The entire expedition was also covered in detail with a special free edition of the [https://em3video.com/masters-magazine-special-edition-free-spring-2019/ Masters Magazine] aptly called \"The Phoenix Rises.<ref>{{Cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: *Draeger, Donn F. (1979). ''An Introduction to Hoplology: Part I of II,'' Hoplos 1:1
*Draeger, Donn F. (1979). ''An Introduction to Hoplology: Part II of II,'' Hoplos 1:2
'''José''' or '''Joseph Penso de la Vega''', best known as '''Josseph de la Vega''' (ca. 1650 — Amsterdam, November 13, 1692), was a Spanish [[Sephardi Jews
date=March 2014}}: Jewish]] merchant, financial expert and poet, residing in 17th century Amsterdam. He became famous for his masterpiece ''Confusion of Confusions''. Vega's work is the first study written about the [[Amsterdam Stock Exchange]]and its participants, the shareholders.<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref> In it he describes the whole gamut, running from options (puts and calls), futures contracts, [[Margin (finance)
column3: margin buying]], to bull and bear conspiracies, even some form of [[Stock market index
column4: stock-index trading]].<ref>De Vries and Van der Woude, p. 151</ref> The publication of Confusion de Confusiones helped lay the foundations for modern fields of [[technical analysis]] and [[behavioral finance]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: [[File:Gerrit Berckheyde - View of the Two Synagogues of Amsterdam 259.jpg
column3: View on the two synagogues of Amsterdam from the East by [[Gerrit Berckheyde]]. It is the area where De la Vega grew up. ]]
[[Portuguese Synagogue (Amsterdam)]] from the NW by [[Peter Schenk the Elder]] ]]

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Joseph Penso was born about 1650 into a family of [[Spanish and Portuguese Jews]].<ref>https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/penso-de-la-vega-joseph</ref> He was the son of Isaac Penso Félix (-1683) and of Esther de la Vega (-1679) who was a relative of the Vegas that founded a Talmudic school in [[Livorno]]. His father was a [[Marrano]] from Espejo, a small town in [[Córdoba (Spanish province)
date=March 2014}}: Córdoba province]] ([[Andalusia]], Spain), who had made a solemn vow in the dungeon of the [[Inquisition]] that within a year after regaining his liberty he would openly profess [[Judaism]]. This oath he seems to have fulfilled in [[Middelburg]] after his escape to [[Antwerp]].<ref>[https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/vega002conf01_01/vega002conf01_01_0009.php Confusion de Confusiones(1939)–Joseph de la Vega by G.J. Geers]</ref> He moved to Hamburg, where he married Esther de la Vega.<ref>https://www.dutchjewry.org/portuguese_israelite_cemetery/popup.htm?../P.I.G./image/01961201.jpg</ref> Sara, their first child, was born there in 1645.{{efn
column3: When Sara Pensa married in 1669 her father Isaac assisted her. The couple had the City Archives four more daughters who married in Amsterdam and used either their father's or mother's last name: Jochebet or Jocqueba Pensa (1655-1718) and Ribca Penso (1662-1720) who married on the same day in 1685, and Abigail Penso (ca 1663-1708) and Lea Pensa (1664-1710).<ref>https://www.dutchjewry.org/genealogy/vega/281.shtml; https://www.dutchjewry.org/portuguese_israelite_cemetery/p.shtml</ref>}} In an unknown year the family settled in Amsterdam.{{efn
column4: In 1647 Moses Penso married Hester Pensa. They both came from Lisbon and lived on [[Vlooienburg]]. The couple was assisted by Raphael Penso and Abigail Pensa. They could have been Joseph' uncle, grandfather and aunts.<ref>[https://archief.amsterdam/archief/5001/679 Amsterdam City Archives]</ref>}} <!--From the time of his marriage until his death distributed 40,000 [[gulden]] as [[tithe]]s from his profits as a merchant.<ref>[https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/vega002conf01_01/vega002conf01_01_0009.php Confusion de Confusiones(1939)–Joseph de la Vega by G.J. Geers]</ref>--> Joseph had according the marriage certificates in the [[Amsterdam City Archives]] three younger brothers: Abraham (ca 1656-1710) was a schoolmaster; David (1654-) and Raphael (ca 1659-) were merchants, who married on the same day in December 1687 two sisters Alvares Vega from Antwerp.{{efn
column5: In 1687 David, Raphael and Lea had moved from [[Rapenburg (Amsterdam)
column7: Haarlemmerbuurt]]. It is not known if Joseph moved also.}} Between 1700 and 1710 they acted as agents in London for Dutch investors.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=3uJADgAAQBAJ&pg=PT345&lpg=PT345&dq=%22Raphael+Penso%22+London&source=bl&ots=7q8dwqqJvQ&sig=ACfU3U3kbdejW2xQkA0j8eX9cZQWu503Zg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwio14q55c_oAhUtMewKHSsLCuwQ6AEwAXoECAsQKQ#v=onepage&q=%22Raphael%20Penso%22%20London&f=false The Financial Revolution in England: A Study in the Development of Public ... by P.G.M. Dickson]</ref> The former moved to Dublin, see [[Ballybough Cemetery]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Joseph was taught by [[Isaac Aboab da Fonseca]] and [[Moses Raphael de Aguilar]], members of the [[Talmud Torah]] community.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=NCvyi5_m6ScC&pg=PA451&dq=joseph+Amsterdam+%22de+la+Vega%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiRnef_k87oAhULsaQKHYTbCQ0Q6AEIQjAE#v=onepage&q=joseph%20Amsterdam%20%22de%20la%20Vega%22&f=false The Anglo-Dutch Moment: Essays on the Glorious Revolution and Its World Impact by Jonathan Irvine Israel, 451]</ref> When in his eighteenth year he completed his first Hebrew drama, \"Asire ha-Tiḳwah\" (\"Pardes Shoshannim\"), in three acts, which appeared in Amsterdam in 1673 (2d ed., Leghorn, 1770), and in which he allegorically depicted the victory of the will over the passions. He married Rachel Alvaro (Alvares?)<ref>https://www.dutchjewry.org/portuguese_israelite_cemetery/popup.htm?../P.I.G./image/01961801.jpg</ref> His active commercial life began in Amsterdam in 1683,<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref> after his father died. He became a respected merchant and an elegant Spanish poet, and filled the honorary offices of president of the Academia de los Sitibundos and in 1685 as secretary of the Academia de los Floridos, founded by [[Manuel de Belmonte]].<ref>[https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/vega002conf01_01/vega002conf01_01_0009.php Confusion de Confusiones(1939)–Joseph de la Vega by G.J. Geers]</ref> Joseph de la Vega, who used his mother last name, wrote over 200 letters to different princes and statesmen, and was a prolific author, \"the marvel of the academies, who made his work proof against criticism by presenting his subject in ordered form; delicate in his sentiments and of true refinement\", as De Barrios (\"Arbol de las Vidas\", p. 90) characterizes him. <!--At the end of his life he moved to Livorno, where he may have died.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=NCvyi5_m6ScC&pg=PA451&dq=joseph+Amsterdam+%22de+la+Vega%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiRnef_k87oAhULsaQKHYTbCQ0Q6AEIQjAE#v=onepage&q=joseph%20Amsterdam%20%22de%20la%20Vega%22&f=false The Anglo-Dutch Moment: Essays on the Glorious Revolution and Its World Impact by Jonathan Irvine Israel, 451]</ref>--> Joseph de la Vega lived in the collapse of the [[Dutch East India Company]], which financially ruined him.<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref> Also [[Coenraad van Beuningen]] lost half a million guilder in 1688 through speculation in VOC shares. He wrote letters to the ecclesiastical authorities about the end of time and painted Hebrew or [[Kabbalistic]] signs on his house.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=B1E4DgAAQBAJ&pg=PT28&lpg=PT28&dq=de+la+Vega+Livorno+Talmud&source=bl&ots=_OyBZuF9W8&sig=ACfU3U3MEHadCOo5ooiMt8nz1BUwudFouA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjHiYWw1NroAhWByaQKHWDXDy4Q6AEwAXoECAwQKQ#v=onepage&q=de%20la%20Vega%20Livorno%20Talmud&f=false A Concise Financial History of Europe Learning from the innovations of the early bankers, traders and fund managers by taking a historical journey through Europe’s main financial centers. Jan Sytze Mosselaar © 2018 Robeco, Rotterdam]</ref> The funding of the armed invasion of [[William III of England
date=March 2014}}: William III]] in England caused a financial crisis in the Dutch Republic. Consequently, the financiers following William III to Britain possessed a full range of financial techniques, and for which they found a ready market indeed. This transfer of know-how formed the basis of [[Derivative (finance)
column3: derivatives]] trading in London, firmly linking Amsterdam's pioneering work to the emergence of modern markets.<ref>[https://www.yumpu.com/en/document/read/20528807/amsterdam-as-the-cradle-of-modern-futures-and-options-trading- Amsterdam as the cradle of modern futures and options (1550-1650), p. 15 by Oscar Gelderblom and Joost Jonker. Utrecht University, 2005]</ref>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: [[File:Emanuel de Witte - De binnenplaats van de beurs te Amsterdam.jpg
column3: Courtyard of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange by [[Emanuel de Witte]] (1653)]]
Courtyard of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange by [[Job Berckheyde]], circa 1670.]]

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Although not a descriptive account of the process of stock trading, Joseph presented the history of speculation in stocks and acquainted the reader with the sophisticated financial instruments used. The dialogue format allowed the reader to understand the respective perspectives of the various market participants and the intricacies of speculation and trading. There is evidence in Confusion de Confusiones of three major biases: [[herding]], [[overconfidence]], and regret aversion.<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref>  The book is written in Spanish; its original title is ''Confusión de Confusiones''.<ref>It is possible to read it in a full view mode here [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?view=1up;size=100;id=uc1.32106019504239;page=root;seq=1;orient=0] or buy here {{cite web

column3: text=Joseph also came up with four basic rules of the share market that are still of the greatest relevance today:}}

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: ''The first rule in speculation is: Never advise anyone to buy or sell shares. Where guessing correctly is a form of witchcraft, counsel cannot be put on airs.''
''The second rule: Accept both your profits and regrets. It is best to seize what comes to hand when it comes, and not expect that your good fortune and the favorable circumstances will last.''
''The third rule: Profit in the share market is goblin treasure: at one moment, it is [[carbuncle (gemstone)
date=March 2014}}: carbuncle]]s, the next it is coal; one moment diamonds, and the next pebbles. Sometimes, they are the tears that Aurora leaves on the sweet morning's grass, at other times, they are just tears.''

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: ''The fourth rule: He who wishes to become rich from this game must have both money and patience.''

Confusion de Confusiones remained little known until the German economist [[Richard Ehrenberg]] published an influential essay in the 1892 Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik, “Die Amsterdame Aktienspekulation un 17. Jarhhundert.”<ref>[https://www.sothebys.com/en/articles/the-first-book-to-describe-a-stock-exchange The First Book to Describe a Stock Exchange By Sotheby's]</ref>
In his honour, the {{Interlanguage link multi
column3: de}} (FESE) awards since 2000 the annual [[De La Vega Prize]] to \"''young European researchers who distinguish themselves by outstanding research on the securities markets in Europe''\".<ref>{{cite web

Geers]</ref> He moved to Hamburg, where he married Esther de la Vega.<ref>https://www.dutchjewry.org/portuguese_israelite_cemetery/popup.htm?../P.I.G./image/01961201.jpg</ref> Sara, their first child, was born there in 1645.{{efn
column3: When Sara Pensa married in 1669 her father Isaac assisted her. The couple had the City Archives four more daughters who married in Amsterdam and used either their father's or mother's last name: Jochebet or Jocqueba Pensa (1655-1718) and Ribca Penso (1662-1720) who married on the same day in 1685, and Abigail Penso (ca 1663-1708) and Lea Pensa (1664-1710).<ref>https://www.dutchjewry.org/genealogy/vega/281.shtml; https://www.dutchjewry.org/portuguese_israelite_cemetery/p.shtml</ref>}} In an unknown year the family settled in Amsterdam.{{efn
column4: In 1647 Moses Penso married Hester Pensa. They both came from Lisbon and lived on [[Vlooienburg]]. The couple was assisted by Raphael Penso and Abigail Pensa. They could have been Joseph' uncle, grandfather and aunts.<ref>[https://archief.amsterdam/archief/5001/679 Amsterdam City Archives]</ref>}} <!--From the time of his marriage until his death distributed 40,000 [[gulden]] as [[tithe]]s from his profits as a merchant.<ref>[https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/vega002conf01_01/vega002conf01_01_0009.php Confusion de Confusiones(1939)–Joseph de la Vega by G.J. Geers]</ref>--> Joseph had according the marriage certificates in the [[Amsterdam City Archives]] three younger brothers: Abraham (ca 1656-1710) was a schoolmaster; David (1654-) and Raphael (ca 1659-) were merchants, who married on the same day in December 1687 two sisters Alvares Vega from Antwerp.{{efn
column5: In 1687 David, Raphael and Lea had moved from [[Rapenburg (Amsterdam)
column7: Haarlemmerbuurt]]. It is not known if Joseph moved also.}} Between 1700 and 1710 they acted as agents in London for Dutch investors.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=3uJADgAAQBAJ&pg=PT345&lpg=PT345&dq=%22Raphael+Penso%22+London&source=bl&ots=7q8dwqqJvQ&sig=ACfU3U3kbdejW2xQkA0j8eX9cZQWu503Zg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwio14q55c_oAhUtMewKHSsLCuwQ6AEwAXoECAsQKQ#v=onepage&q=%22Raphael%20Penso%22%20London&f=false The Financial Revolution in England: A Study in the Development of Public ... by P.G.M. Dickson]</ref> The former moved to Dublin, see [[Ballybough Cemetery]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Joseph was taught by [[Isaac Aboab da Fonseca]] and [[Moses Raphael de Aguilar]], members of the [[Talmud Torah]] community.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=NCvyi5_m6ScC&pg=PA451&dq=joseph+Amsterdam+%22de+la+Vega%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiRnef_k87oAhULsaQKHYTbCQ0Q6AEIQjAE#v=onepage&q=joseph%20Amsterdam%20%22de%20la%20Vega%22&f=false The Anglo-Dutch Moment: Essays on the Glorious Revolution and Its World Impact by Jonathan Irvine Israel, 451]</ref> When in his eighteenth year he completed his first Hebrew drama, \"Asire ha-Tiḳwah\" (\"Pardes Shoshannim\"), in three acts, which appeared in Amsterdam in 1673 (2d ed., Leghorn, 1770), and in which he allegorically depicted the victory of the will over the passions. He married Rachel Alvaro (Alvares?)<ref>https://www.dutchjewry.org/portuguese_israelite_cemetery/popup.htm?../P.I.G./image/01961801.jpg</ref> His active commercial life began in Amsterdam in 1683,<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref> after his father died. He became a respected merchant and an elegant Spanish poet, and filled the honorary offices of president of the Academia de los Sitibundos and in 1685 as secretary of the Academia de los Floridos, founded by [[Manuel de Belmonte]].<ref>[https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/vega002conf01_01/vega002conf01_01_0009.php Confusion de Confusiones(1939)–Joseph de la Vega by G.J. Geers]</ref> Joseph de la Vega, who used his mother last name, wrote over 200 letters to different princes and statesmen, and was a prolific author, \"the marvel of the academies, who made his work proof against criticism by presenting his subject in ordered form; delicate in his sentiments and of true refinement\", as De Barrios (\"Arbol de las Vidas\", p. 90) characterizes him. <!--At the end of his life he moved to Livorno, where he may have died.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=NCvyi5_m6ScC&pg=PA451&dq=joseph+Amsterdam+%22de+la+Vega%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiRnef_k87oAhULsaQKHYTbCQ0Q6AEIQjAE#v=onepage&q=joseph%20Amsterdam%20%22de%20la%20Vega%22&f=false The Anglo-Dutch Moment: Essays on the Glorious Revolution and Its World Impact by Jonathan Irvine Israel, 451]</ref>--> Joseph de la Vega lived in the collapse of the [[Dutch East India Company]], which financially ruined him.<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref> Also [[Coenraad van Beuningen]] lost half a million guilder in 1688 through speculation in VOC shares. He wrote letters to the ecclesiastical authorities about the end of time and painted Hebrew or [[Kabbalistic]] signs on his house.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=B1E4DgAAQBAJ&pg=PT28&lpg=PT28&dq=de+la+Vega+Livorno+Talmud&source=bl&ots=_OyBZuF9W8&sig=ACfU3U3MEHadCOo5ooiMt8nz1BUwudFouA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjHiYWw1NroAhWByaQKHWDXDy4Q6AEwAXoECAwQKQ#v=onepage&q=de%20la%20Vega%20Livorno%20Talmud&f=false A Concise Financial History of Europe Learning from the innovations of the early bankers, traders and fund managers by taking a historical journey through Europe’s main financial centers. Jan Sytze Mosselaar © 2018 Robeco, Rotterdam]</ref> The funding of the armed invasion of [[William III of England
date=March 2014}}: William III]] in England caused a financial crisis in the Dutch Republic. Consequently, the financiers following William III to Britain possessed a full range of financial techniques, and for which they found a ready market indeed. This transfer of know-how formed the basis of [[Derivative (finance)
column3: derivatives]] trading in London, firmly linking Amsterdam's pioneering work to the emergence of modern markets.<ref>[https://www.yumpu.com/en/document/read/20528807/amsterdam-as-the-cradle-of-modern-futures-and-options-trading- Amsterdam as the cradle of modern futures and options (1550-1650), p. 15 by Oscar Gelderblom and Joost Jonker. Utrecht University, 2005]</ref>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: [[File:Emanuel de Witte - De binnenplaats van de beurs te Amsterdam.jpg
column3: Courtyard of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange by [[Emanuel de Witte]] (1653)]]
Courtyard of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange by [[Job Berckheyde]], circa 1670.]]

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Although not a descriptive account of the process of stock trading, Joseph presented the history of speculation in stocks and acquainted the reader with the sophisticated financial instruments used. The dialogue format allowed the reader to understand the respective perspectives of the various market participants and the intricacies of speculation and trading. There is evidence in Confusion de Confusiones of three major biases: [[herding]], [[overconfidence]], and regret [[aversion]]{{dn
date=March 2014}}: date=April 2020}}.<ref>Teresa Corzo, Margarita Prat & Esther Vaquero (2014) Behavioral Finance in Joseph de la Vega's Confusion de Confusiones, Journal of Behavioral Finance, 15:4, 341-350, DOI: 10.1080/15427560.2014.968722</ref>  The book is written in Spanish; its original title is ''Confusión de Confusiones''.<ref>It is possible to read it in a full view mode here [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?view=1up;size=100;id=uc1.32106019504239;page=root;seq=1;orient=0] or buy here {{cite web

column3: text=Joseph also came up with four basic rules of the share market that are still of the greatest relevance today:}}

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: ''The first rule in speculation is: Never advise anyone to buy or sell shares. Where guessing correctly is a form of witchcraft, counsel cannot be put on airs.''
''The second rule: Accept both your profits and regrets. It is best to seize what comes to hand when it comes, and not expect that your good fortune and the favorable circumstances will last.''
''The third rule: Profit in the share market is goblin treasure: at one moment, it is [[carbuncle (gemstone)
date=March 2014}}: carbuncle]]s, the next it is coal; one moment diamonds, and the next pebbles. Sometimes, they are the tears that Aurora leaves on the sweet morning's grass, at other times, they are just tears.''

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: ''The fourth rule: He who wishes to become rich from this game must have both money and patience.''

Confusion de Confusiones remained little known until the German economist [[Richard Ehrenberg]] published an influential essay in the 1892 Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik, “Die Amsterdame Aktienspekulation un 17. Jarhhundert.”<ref>[https://www.sothebys.com/en/articles/the-first-book-to-describe-a-stock-exchange The First Book to Describe a Stock Exchange By Sotheby's]</ref>
In his honour, the {{Interlanguage link multi
column3: de}} (FESE) awards since 2000 the annual [[De La Vega Prize]] to \"''young European researchers who distinguish themselves by outstanding research on the securities markets in Europe''\".<ref>{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: *''Discurso académico moral. Hecho en la Insigne Academia de los Sitibundos'' (Amsterdam, 1683; dedicated to Isaac Senior Texeira in Hamburg).
*''Triunfos del águila y eclipses de la luna'' (ib. 1683).
*''La Rosa, Panegírico Sacro, Hecho en la Insigne Academia de los Sitibundos'' (ib. 1683).
*''Rumbos peligrosos por donde navega con título de novelas la zozobrante nave de la temeridad'' (Antwerp, 1684).
*''Discursos académicos, morales, retóricos, y sagrados. Recitados en la Florida Academia de los Floridos'' (ib. 1685).
*''Retrato de la Prudencia, y simulacro del Valor, al Augusto Monarca Guilielmo Tercero, Rey de la Gran Bretaña'' (ib. 1690).
*[https://d2b4hhdj1xs9hu.cloudfront.net/RJ9J589S.jpg Jewish Encyclopedia]   {{JewishEncyclopedia}}  The article on Penso, Joseph was written by [[Isidore Singer]] and [[Meyer Kayserling]]

* [https://books.google.nl/books?id=B1E4DgAAQBAJ&pg=PT28&lpg=PT28&dq=de+la+Vega+Livorno+Talmud&source=bl&ots=_OyBZuF9W8&sig=ACfU3U3MEHadCOo5ooiMt8nz1BUwudFouA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjHiYWw1NroAhWByaQKHWDXDy4Q6AEwAXoECAwQKQ#v=onepage&q=de%20la%20Vega%20Livorno%20Talmud&f=false Pricing the Future: Finance, Physics, and the 300-year Journey to the Black ...by George G. Szpiro]

* [https://www.jstor.org/stable/41482458?seq=1 Penso's Roots: The Politics and Poetics of Cultural Fusion by Eleazar Gutwirth. Studia Rosenthaliana, Vol. 35, No. 2 (2001), pp. 269-284.] Published by: Peeters Publishers. https://www.jstor.org/stable/41482458

column6: Up Close and Personal (Angie Martinez album)

column3: ''Golden Girl: The Story of Jessica Savitch''

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: '''''Up Close & Personal''''' is a 1996 American [[romantic drama film]] directed by [[Jon Avnet]], and starring [[Robert Redford]] as a news director and [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] as his protegée, with [[Stockard Channing]], [[Joe Mantegna]], and [[Kate Nelligan]] in supporting roles.

The screenplay began as an adaptation of ''Golden Girl: The Story of Jessica Savitch'', a 1988 book by [[Alanna Nash]] that recounted the troubled life of American news anchor [[Jessica Savitch]]. The finished picture, however, was greatly altered by commercial decisions on the part of the producers, and bore little resemblance to Savitch's biography. Screenwriter [[John Gregory Dunne]], having spent eight years working on the script with his wife [[Joan Didion]], later wrote a book describing his difficult experience, titled ''[[Monster: Living Off the Big Screen]]''.
The film was nominated for an [[Academy Awards
date=March 2014}}: Oscar]] in the category of [[Academy Award for Best Original Song
column3: Best Original Song]] for \"[[Because You Loved Me]]\", written by [[Diane Warren]] and performed by [[Celine Dion]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Sally \"Tally\" Atwater ([[Michelle Pfeiffer]]) is an ambitious, aspiring news reporter, who is hired by [[Miami]] local news director Warren Justice ([[Robert Redford]]) when she sends in a homemade audition tape. He carefully guides her career to new heights, all the while becoming increasingly attracted to her.

Tally soon rises through the ranks of network news to become successful, while Warren's once-stellar career sinks into mediocrity. Furthermore, Tally's ascension takes her away from Warren when she is forced to relocate to [[Philadelphia]]. Tally struggles at her new post, in no small part due to the hostility of veteran reporter Marcia McGrath ([[Stockard Channing]]), who jealously protects her position as the top reporter. Warren turns up to inspire Tally, and the two partners begin a new career together.

However, on a routine assignment in a Philadelphia prison, Tally and her cameraman are taken hostage in a prison riot and forced to endure hours of intense violence. Tally covers the groundbreaking story from within the walls of the collapsing prison as Warren looks on from outside, guiding her through her first national broadcast. This incredible act of bravery leads to Tally's eagerly anticipated advancement to a national network newscaster position and the continuation of the dynamic duo's rise to fame - but shortly after, disaster strikes when Warren is killed during an assignment.

In the spring of 1988, [[John Gregory Dunne]] and [[Joan Didion]] began writing the script for a film entitled ''Golden Girl'', based on [[Alanna Nash]]'s biography of the late [[NBC News]] anchor and reporter [[Jessica Savitch]] and financed by [[The Walt Disney Company]]. When the film was finally released in 1996, eight years later, it was known as ''Up Close & Personal'' and none of the more controversial details of Savitch's life remained, including her alleged drug abuse problems that may have caused her to deliver an incoherent live news update on national television in early October 1983.<ref name=haller>{{cite magazine
column5: title=The Two Faces of a Newswoman
column14: access-date=2016-03-06 }}</ref> Other details omitted from the film included the suicide of Savitch's second husband a few months after their wedding, and her alleged bisexuality, suicide attempts, abortion, and [[domestic violence
column15: physical abuse]] by her longtime partner [[Ron Kershaw]], a well-known news director who was the original model for the character of Warren Justice.<ref name=muddle>{{cite newspaper
column19: title=A Beginning, a Muddle and an End
column30: title=Jessica Savaged: How Hollywood Heterosexualized ''Up Close & Personal''
column37: access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> Savitch's death at age 36 in an automobile accident (unrelated to drugs or alcohol) was also left out of the screenplay.<ref name=haller />

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: According to Dunne, who chronicled his experiences dealing with studio executives in his book ''[[Monster: Living Off the Big Screen]]'', the majority of these changes were made in order to appeal to a broader mainstream market. Producer [[Scott Rudin]] was reported to have said, when asked by a weary Dunne what the film was supposed to be, \"it's about two movie stars.\"<ref name=muddle />
The film currently holds an approval rating of 31% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 35 reviews, with an average rating of 5/10.<ref>{{cite web

Critics largely ridiculed the screenplay for bearing little resemblance to the biography of [[Jessica Savitch]], which was supposed to have inspired it. [[Roger Ebert]] in the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' wrote: \"''Up Close and Personal'' is so different from the facts of Savitch's life that if [[Joan Didion
column3: Dunne]] still have their first draft, they probably could sell it as a completely different movie.\"<ref name=\"ebert\">{{cite web
column7: title=Up Close And Personal :: rogerebert.com :: Reviews
column9: date=March 1, 1996}}</ref> Anita Gates in the ''[[New York Times]]'' wrote that \"it all ends up more ''[[A Star Is Born (1937 film)
column10: A Star Is Born]]'' than ''[[Network (1976 film)
column15: title=Movie Review - Up Close & Personal - As Naval Engagements Go, Not a Classic
column18: Variety]]'' described it as \"''A Star Is Born'' meets ''[[The Way We Were]]'', and while discerning audiences will turn their noses up, the hoi polloi are apt to embrace this unabashedly sentimental affair and send it soaring into the box office stratosphere.\"<ref name=\"variety\">{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: [[Desson Howe]] in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' was extremely negative about the film: \"''Up Close and Personal'', which was \"suggested\" by the Jessica Savitch biography, ''Golden Girl: The Story of Jessica Savitch'', starts out with relative promise... but then, the loooove comes through like a bad-news feed, and our marquee lovers undergo one of those unbearable montages. While an insipid, rock ballad covers the proceedings with auditory treacle, Cushion Lips ([[Michelle Pfeiffer]]) and Armchair Man ([[Robert Redford]]) walk together, laugh together, frolic in the waves with their clothes on - that sort of thing... In this movie, network executives - who depend entirely on focus groups, marketing and advertisers to inform their decisions - are painted as the moral bad guys, while Redford and the emerging Pfeiffer are the embodiment of integrity... And the fact that this is a [[Touchstone Pictures]] production - part of the marketing-obsessed, truth-sweetening [[Disney]] empire which just purchased [[American Broadcasting Company
date=March 2014}}: ABC]] - is far too hilarious an irony to ignore.\"<ref>{{cite web
column9: Time Out]]'' called it a \"soppy May–December romance masquerading as a deadly earnest issues movie... Blow-dried, bleached blonde-on-bland entertainment.\"<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Review: Up Close & Personal - Film - Time Out London

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: However, certain critics argued that the film had its merits. [[Mick LaSalle]] in the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' wrote: \"Taken on its own terms, ''Up Close and Personal'' is a fine movie. Two star images meet and enhance each other. [[Robert Redford
date=March 2014}}: Redford]], as usual, plays a rugged, outdoorsy, uncompromising man of unshakable integrity who just happens to be news director at a Miami station. [[Michelle Pfeiffer
column3: Pfeiffer]], as usual, is gorgeous, pretty, gawky and a lot tougher and smarter than she looks.\"<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=FILM REVIEW - TV News Made 'Personal' / Redford, Pfeiffer in a fine romance
column9: date=September 13, 1996}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film three out of four stars, arguing that the \"temptations are great to mock the clichés and melodrama in ''Up Close and Personal'', but the movie undeniably works as what it really is - a love story.\"<ref name=\"ebert\"/> ''Variety'' praised the \"chemistry\" of [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] and [[Robert Redford]], and the \"delicious and brief star turns\" of [[Stockard Channing]], [[Kate Nelligan]] and [[Noble Willingham]], concluding that the film wasn't \"as accomplished as its inspiration but, regrettably, it's the best Hollywood has to offer in the heartstring-pulling genre.\"<ref name=\"variety\"/>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The featured song, \"[[Because You Loved Me]]\", written by [[Diane Warren]] and performed by [[Celine Dion]], won the [[Grammy Award for Best Song Written for a Motion Picture, Television or Other Visual Media
date=March 2014}}: Grammy Award for Best Song Written for a Motion Picture or Television]], and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song
column3: Academy Award]] and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song]].<ref name=\"awards\">{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: [[Stockard Channing]] won a [[Blockbuster Entertainment Award]] for Favorite Supporting Actress - Romance.<ref name=\"awards\"/>
The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists:

date=March 2014}}: 1996 American romantic drama film directed by Jon Avnet}}

column7: title=FILM REVIEW - TV News Made 'Personal' / Redford, Pfeiffer in a fine romance
column9: date=September 13, 1996}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film three out of four stars, arguing that the \"temptations are great to mock the clichés and melodrama in ''Up Close and Personal'', but the movie undeniably works as what it really is - a love story.\"<ref name=\"ebert\"/> ''Variety'' praised the \"chemistry\" of [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] and [[Robert Redford]], and the \"delicious and brief star turns\" of [[Stockard Channing]], [[Kate Nelligan]] and [[Noble Willingham]], concluding that the film wasn't \"as accomplished as its inspiration but, regrettably, it's the best Hollywood has to offer in the heartstring-pulling genre.\"<ref name=\"variety\"/>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The featured song, \"[[Because You Loved Me]]\", written by [[Diane Warren]] and performed by [[Celine Dion]], won the [[Grammy Award for Best Song Written for a Motion Picture, Television or Other Visual Media
date=March 2014}}: Grammy Award for Best Song Written for a Motion Picture or Television]], and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song
column3: Academy Award]] and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song]].<ref name=\"awards\">{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: [[Stockard Channing]] won a [[Blockbuster Entertainment Award]] for Favorite Supporting Actress - Romance.<ref name=\"awards\"/>
The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists:

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: '''André du Pon''' (30 August 1924, in [[Amsterdam]] – 24 May 2006, in [[Medemblik]]) was a [[sailor]] from the [[Netherlands]], who was three times chef d'équipe for the Dutch Olympic Sailing team. Du Pon led his teams during the [[Sailing at the 1976 Summer Olympics
date=March 2014}}: 1976 Olympics]] in [[Kingston, Ontario]], the [[Sailing at the 1984 Summer Olympics
column4: Long Beach]] and the [[Sailing at the 1988 Summer Olympics

date=March 2014}}: Finn]] Du Pon was also one of the first [[Soling]] sailors of the Netherlands. He owned the Soling H 4.

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: During the selection for the [[Dutch Olympic Sailing Team]] for the [[Sailing at the 1976 Summer Olympics
date=March 2014}}: 1976 Olympics]] a controversy emerged between twelve sailors and the [[Koninklijk Nederlands Watersport Verbond
column3: selection committee]] chaired by [[Andre de Pon
column4: Du Pon]]. This discussion focussed on the role of [[Frieda Vollebergt]] who did the communication for the sailing team. As mother of [[Erik Vollebregt]], [[Sjoerd Vollebregt]] and [[Peter Vollebregt]] - All three candidates for the 1976 Olympic sailing event - she was accused of having a [[bias]] towards her children in the communication. In the end [[Fred Imhoff]] and [[Heike Blok]] lost the [[lawsuit]] and were removed from the 1976 selection.

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Du Pon was in the period 1990 - 1998 and from 2002 - 2006 [[alderman]] for the liberal party [[VVD]] in [[Medemblik]]. During those periods he held several times the position of [[deputy mayor]].

title=Sony Pictures Animation Promotes Pam Marsden to Head of Production

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: '''Sony Pictures Animation Inc.''' is an American [[animation studio]] owned by [[Sony Pictures
date=March 2014}}: Sony Pictures Entertainment]] through their [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group
column3: Motion Picture Group]] division and founded on May 9, 2002. The studio's films are distributed worldwide by [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group#Sony Pictures Releasing
column4: Sony Pictures Releasing]] under their [[Columbia Pictures]] label, while all direct-to-video releases are released by [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment]].

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The first film produced by Sony Pictures Animation, ''[[Open Season (2006 film)
date=March 2014}}: Open Season]]'', was released on September 29, 2006. Its latest release was ''[[The Angry Birds Movie 2]]'' on August 13, 2019, with their next scheduled release set to be ''[[Connected (2020 film)

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: In 2001, [[Sony Pictures]] considered selling off its visual effects facility [[Sony Pictures Imageworks]]. After failing to find a suitable buyer, having been impressed with the [[Computer-generated imagery
date=March 2014}}: CGI]] sequences of ''[[Stuart Little 2]]'' and seeing the box office successes of [[DreamWorks Animation]]'s ''[[Shrek]]'' and [[Walt Disney Pictures
column3: Disney]]/[[Pixar]]'s ''[[Monsters, Inc.]]'', SPI was reconfigured to become an animation studio. ''[[Astro Boy (film)
column4: Astro Boy]]'', which had been in development at Sony since 1997 as a live-action film, was set to be SPI's first all-CGI film, but never made it to fruition.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Sony finds Rx for its f/x
column11: date=December 9, 2001}}</ref> On May 9, 2002, Sony Pictures Animation was established to develop characters, stories and movies with SPI taking over the digital production while maintaining its visual effects production.<ref>{{Cite press release
column12: title = Sony Pictures Digital Entertainment Establishes Feature Animation Unit; Animation Executives Sandra Rabins and Penney Finkelman Cox Named to Top Posts
column15: accessdate = August 1, 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile, SPI produced two short films, the [[Academy Award]]-winning ''[[The ChubbChubbs!]]'' and ''[[Early Bloomer]]'', as a result of testing its strengths and weaknesses in producing all-CGI animation.<ref>{{cite web

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: On its first anniversary on May 9, 2003, Sony Pictures Animation announced a full slate of animated projects in development: ''[[Open Season (2006 film)
date=March 2014}}: Open Season]]'', an adaptation of a Celtic folk ballad ''[[Tam Lin]]'', ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (film)
column3: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs]]'', ''[[Surf's Up (film)
column4: Surf's Up]]'', and a feature-length film version of ''The ChubbChubbs!''.<ref>{{Cite press release
column5: title = Sony Pictures Animation Announces Projects for Directors Jill Culton, Anthony Stacchi, Roger Allers, Brenda Chapman and the Brizzi Brothers Cox Named to Top Posts

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Its first feature film was ''[[Open Season (2006 film)
date=March 2014}}: Open Season]]'', released in September 2006, which became Sony's second-highest-grossing home entertainment film in 2007 and spawned three [[direct-to-video]] [[sequel]]s. Its second feature film, ''[[Surf's Up (film)
column3: Surf's Up]]'' was released in June 2007, was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Animated Feature]], and won two Annie Awards. A [[Motion capture
column11: accessdate=August 1, 2011}}</ref> and written and produced by [[Jon Favreau]], was cancelled sometime in 2008<ref>{{cite web
column18: accessdate=August 1, 2011}}</ref> after four years in development. SPA's first 3D movie since the IMAX 3D release of ''[[Open Season (2006 film)
column19: Open Season]]'', ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (film)
column20: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs]]'', was released in September 2009 and was nominated for four Annie Awards, including Best Animated Feature. ''[[The Smurfs (film)
column21: The Smurfs]]'' (2011) was the studio's first CGI/live-action hybrid. SPA's parent company [[Sony Pictures]] had partnered in 2007 with [[Aardman Animations]] to finance, co-produce and distribute feature films.<ref>{{cite news
column27: accessdate=November 7, 2010}}</ref> Together, they produced two films: ''[[Arthur Christmas]]'' (2011), and ''[[The Pirates! In an Adventure with Scientists!
column28: The Pirates! Band of Misfits]]'' (2012), which was SPA's first stop-motion film. In September 2012, SPA released ''[[Hotel Transylvania]]'', which grossed over $350 million worldwide and launched a successful [[Hotel Transylvania (franchise)
column29: franchise]] with two [[sequel]]s and a [[Hotel Transylvania: The Television Series
column30: TV series]]. Two [[sequel]]s are released in 2013: ''[[The Smurfs 2]]'' and ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2]]''. SPA's latest releases are ''[[Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse]]'', an animated [[superhero film]] based on the [[Spider-Man]] comics and featuring the [[Miles Morales]] incarnation of the character, and ''[[The Angry Birds Movie 2]]'', a sequel to the 2016 film ''[[The Angry Birds Movie]]'' produced by [[Rovio Animation]]. SPA has since signed [[Genndy Tartakovsky]] to a long-term deal with the studio to develop and direct original films.<ref>{{cite news
column31: title=Genndy Tartakovsky Signs Overall Deal with Sony Pictures Animation

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The studio is currently working on ''[[Connected (2020 film)
date=March 2014}}: Connected]]'', a robot apocalypse/road trip film written and directed by Michael Rianda and Jeff Rowe while produced by [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]] (2020),<ref name=\"SPAVariety\">{{cite web
column4: title= Annecy: Kristine Belson on Sony Pictures Animation's upcoming slate
column10: access-date=October 5, 2017}}</ref> ''Vivo'', and ''Hotel Transylvania 4'' (2021), and a sequel to ''Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse'' (2022). It has many other projects in development, including an animated ''[[Ghostbusters (franchise)#Animated film
column11: Ghostbusters]]'' spin-off film,<ref name=\"The Wrap\">{{cite web
column14: title='Ghostbusters' Animated Movie in the Works at Sony Pictures Animation
column20: title=Ghostbusters: Ecto Force postponed for new film
column24: date=August 7, 2017}}</ref> an untitled film from Jon Saunders,<ref name=AnimationDevelop>{{cite web
column26: title=A List Of American Animated Features Currently In Development
column29: accessdate=August 21, 2017}}</ref> and two Genndy Tartakovsky projects: an [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#Ratings
column30: R-rated]] comedy titled ''Fixed'' and ''Black Knight''.<ref name=\"DGTSA\">{{cite web
column31: title='Hotel Transylvania' Helmer Genndy Tartakovsky Sets New Projects At Sony Pictures Animation

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: On November 3, 2014, the studio collaborated with [[Frederator Studios]]' [[Cartoon Hangover]] on ''[[GO! Cartoons]]'', an incubator series consisting of 12 short films, with at least one short film being developed into a series. The short films were funded by SPA, with the additional goal of attracting new talent for the studio.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Sony Partners with Cartoon Hangover to Find New Talent
column10: title=Sony Animation & Cartoon Hangover Launch 1st Incubator Film 'The Summoning'

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: According to [[Kristine Belson]], president of SPA, the studio produces films on a 1:1 development-to-production ratio, meaning that the studio puts films into development as much as it places films in production, unlike other animation studios.<ref name=\"SPAVariety\" />
The studio has plans to produce adult animated content for digital platforms.<ref name=\"SPAVariety\" />

In a similar fashion to the [[Warner Animation Group]] and [[Paramount Animation]], the studio outsources their films to other animation companies and visual effects studios, with the majority of their films being animated by [[Sony Pictures Imageworks]] (its sister company). Some films, such as ''[[Arthur Christmas]], [[The Pirates! Band of Misfits]],'' ''[[The Angry Birds Movie 2]]'' and ''[[Wish Dragon]]'', were acquired by Sony Pictures Animation to be released under their banner while others, such as ''[[Goosebumps (film)
column3: Peter Rabbit]]'', were made with no involvement from the studio.

date=March 2014}}: List of Sony Pictures Animation productions}}

column3: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs]]''

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: *[[List of unproduced Sony Pictures Animation projects]]
[[Category:Film production companies of the United States]]

column5: Aerial view of farms and forest in [[Ydre Municipality]].]]
The forested landscape of the South Swedish highlands, seen from [[Skuruhatt]] in [[Eksjö Municipality]].]]

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The '''South Swedish highlands''' or '''South Swedish Uplands'''<ref name=Karna2017/> ({{lang-sv
column3: Sydsvenska höglandet}}) is a hilly area covering large parts of [[Götaland]] in southern  [[Sweden]]. Except for a lack of deep valleys, the landscape is similar to the [[Norrland terrain]] found further north in Sweden.<ref>{{cite book
column15: language=Swedish}}</ref> The central-eastern parts of the highlands contain about thirty narrow canyons locally known as ''skurus''.<ref>{{cite journal

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Much of the highlands lies above 200 [[m.a.s.l.]] and there are large areas around the highlands that exceed 100 m.a.s.l. The highlands are centered on [[Småland]] but cover also large swathes of [[Scania]], [[Halland]], [[Västergötland]], [[Östergötland]] and [[Blekinge]].<ref>{{cite book
column13: language=Swedish}}</ref> The highest point lies 377 m.a.s.l.<ref name=LB2013>{{cite journal
column22: title=Stratigraphic Landscape Analysis and geomorphological paradigms: Scandinavia as an example of Phanerozoic uplift and subsidence

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The South Swedish highlands have been populated since the [[Nordic Stone Age]] as evidenced by [[cist]] findings.<ref name=skogskunskap/> During the [[Nordic Bronze Age]] (c. 1700–500 BC) there was a significant agricultural expansion across the highlands. Soils developed on [[till
date=March 2014}}: glacial till]] were cleared with stones being pile-up in cairns.<ref name=skogskunskap/><ref name=Per2013>{{cite journal
column5: title=Agrara fluktuationer och befolknings-utveckling på sydsvenska höglandet tolkade utifrån röjningsrösen
column12: language=Swedish}}</ref> Other periods of agricultural expansion are the [[Archaeology_of_Northern_Europe#Roman_Iron_Age
column13: Roman Iron Age]] and the [[High Middle Ages]] (c. 13th century).<ref name=Per2013/>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Poor soil conditions have posed significant difficulties for agriculture in the highlands, meaning that over time small industries became relatively important in local economies.<ref name=skogskunskap/> Many abandoned fields are now covered with forest. Vestiges of abandoned fields can be recognised through the highlands by characteristic heaps of stones made when soils where cleared for cultivation.<ref name=skogskunskap>{{cite web
The climate of the western parts of the highlands is more humid than on the east. This is due to [[orographic precipitation]] caused by [[westerlies
date=March 2014}}: southwestern]] wind forcing moist air over the highlands.<ref name=SMHIsmaland/> [[Sommen
column3: Lake Sommen]] in the northeastern part of the highlands har relatively low humidity and low precipitations.<ref name=sodra2015>{{cite report
column7: chapter=4. östra Götalands sprickdals- och eklandskap
column10: trans-title=Forest biodiversity regions in southern Sweden
column17: language=Swedish }}</ref> [[Ljungby]] in the southwestern parts of the highlands hold the monthly precipitation record for Småland with 347 mm in August 1945.<ref name=SMHIsmaland/> The South Swedish highlands host the record locations for coldest and hottest temperatures in [[Götaland
column25: date=January 16, 2018}}</ref> The cold record is -38.5 °C on January 16 1918 in [[Lommaryd]].<ref name=SMHIsmaland/> While the hot record is 38 °C on June 29, 1947 in [[Målilla]].<ref name=SMHIsmaland/>

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: The South Swedish highlands are less exposed to storms than the southern and [[Swedish West Coast
date=March 2014}}: western]] coasts of Sweden, yet storms can still be very destructive.<ref name=SMHIsmaland/> The [[Cyclone Gudrun
column3: 2005 storm Gudrun]] was particularly strong causing much damage to forests in the southwestern part of the highlands.<ref name=SMHIsmaland/><ref name=SMHIGudrun>{{cite web
column11: Spruces]] were particularly hit by Gudrun, while other trees with a more steady root system fared better.<ref name=SMHIGudrun/> Damage was exacerbated by the intential planting of spruces and practice of [[clearcutting]] which left many trees exposed to the wind.<ref name=SMHIGudrun/> Gudrun also caused [[Power outage
column12: blackouts]] and disabled telecommunications infrastructure through the highlands.<ref name=SMHIsmaland/><ref name=SMHIGudrun/>

column5: Map centered on the South Swedish highlands.]]

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: Within a geological context the highlands are the expression of the South Swedish Dome.<ref name=LB2013/> The South Swedish Dome has been subsided and been uplifted multiple times by [[epeirogeny
date=March 2014}}: epeirogenic movements]] during the [[Phanerozoic]]. The dome has had periods of subsidence and burial in sediments have alternated with periods of exhumation and the formation of [[peneplain]]s and hilly relief. The [[Sub-Cambrian peneplain]] of [[Neoproterozoic
column3: Late Neoproterozoic]] age is the oldest of the surfaces. It covers the eastern and northern flanks of the dome and its crest region where it is up-broken.<ref name=Japsenetal2016/><ref name=NatenSSH>{{cite web
column14: language=Swedish}}</ref> The mesozoic-aged Sub-Mesozoic hilly relief covers the southern and western fringes of the dome, corresponding roughly with the counties of [[Halland]], [[Blekinge]] and northeastern [[Scania]]. The youngest well-defined surface is the [[South Småland peneplain]] that formed in the [[Neogene]].<ref name=Japsenetal2016>{{cite journal
column24: title=Episodic burial and exhumation of the southern Baltic Shield: Epeirogenic uplifts during and after break-up of Pangaea
column30: bibcode=2016GondR..35..357J }}</ref> In detail the South Swedish Dome has the form of a [[piedmonttreppen]] or staircase of erosion surfaces. From top to bottom the levels  are:<ref name=Karna2017>{{cite journal
column39: title=The South Swedish Dome: a key structure for identification of peneplains and conclusions on Phanerozoic tectonics of an ancient shield

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: *the crestal and upbroken portions of the [[Sub-Cambrian peneplain]]

date=March 2014}}: This level was considered as part of a post-Silurian peneplain by [[Sten Rudberg]] as it could be [[summit accordance
column3: matched]] to hills in [[Västergötland]] ([[Kinnekulle]], [[Halleberg]], [[Hunneberg]] and [[Billingen]]).<ref name=Karna2017/><ref name=Karna1988>{{cite journal
column7: title=Denudation surfaces of a shield area in southern Sweden
column12: doi= }}</ref> [[Karna Lidmar-Bergström]] consider this correlation plausible but the evidence tenuous.<ref name=Karna1988/>}}

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: *the 200 m a.s.l. peneplain, containing various [[inselberg]]s.<ref name=\"NatenSSH\"/>{{efn-ua
date=March 2014}}: The existence of this surface was first noted by S. Nordlindh in 1924 in a monograph about hydropower and topography.<ref name=Karna1988/>}}
The South Småland peneplain was first noted by [[Sten De Geer]] in 1913.<ref name=Karna1988/>}}

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: :*the 100 m a.s.l. surface which is part of the South Småland peneplain
The Late Cenozoic uplift of the dome is tentatively related to far-field compressional stresses that has uplifted the region as a giant [[anticline]]-like [[lithosphere]] [[fold (geology)
date=March 2014}}: fold]]. As such it is similar to uplifted [[passive margin]]s like the [[Scandinavian Mountains]] or the mountains of Western and Eastern [[Greenland]].<ref>{{cite journal
column12: title=Elevated, passive continental margins: Not rift shoulders, but expressions of episodic, post-rift burial and exhumation

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: During the last [[deglaciation]] of the [[Weichselian glaciation
date=March 2014}}: Weichselian Ice Sheet]] the South Swedish highlands was a place of ice flow divergence.<ref name=Sveriges2011>{{cite book
column18: title=Sveriges Geologi: Från urtid till nutid
column27: page=515}}</ref> Deglaciation of southern Sweden was relatively slow with ice margin retreat rates of less than 150 m/yr. The retreat was interrupted multiple times by small glacier advances. These advances led to the formation of a series of [[end moraine]] systems. During deglaciation in southern Sweden glacier ice was mostly warm-based with some lesser parts being [[permafrost

(Typo in),unsafe,31.167.16.176,"{{Engvar: At present various lakes in the South Swedish highlands contain [[plankton]]ic crustacean species that are [[Relict (biology)
date=March 2014}}: relics]] from the time the Weichselian Ice Sheet [[deglaciation
column3: left]] the area about 12,000 years ago.<ref name=Kinsten2010>{{cite report
column8: title=De glacialrelikta kräftdjurens utbredning i södra Sverige  (Götaland och Svealand)
column59: Lake Sommen]] stands out for having as much as three glacial relict crustcean species. These species are ''[[Pallasea
column62: Limnocalanus macrurus]]''. Yet the lake lacks the most common relict crustacean found in the lakes of southern Sweden, the ''[[Mysis relicta]]''.<ref name=Kinsten2010/>

column5: Aerial view of farms and forest in South Swedish highland in [[Ydre Municipality]].]]
The forested landscape of the South Swedish highland  seen from [[Skuruhatt]] in [[Eksjö Municipality]].]]
